FROSH AND SOPHS
TO MEET TOMORROW
Date is Finally Agreed Upon
By Both Classes
FIRST YEAR MEN FAVORED
Lack of Regulations Lessens
Interest
Tomorrow morning Homewood
field will be the scene of much
bloodshed and rivalry. The teams
representing the freshman and
sophomore classes will clash at 11
A. M.
The freshman team will have a
little edge on their opponents due
to the fact that they were organized
early in the season and have played
about a half a dozen games against
other teams representing the freshmen classes of the different colleges.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, DECEMBER 6, 1929

Vol. XXXIV, No. 19

CADET OFFICERS
PLAN SERVICE CLUBS
Plans for the formation of
the Service Club will be decided on and drawn up at a
meeting to be held on Monday, December 9, at 3:45
P. M., on the second floor of
Levering Hall. This meeting
will be held for all the cadet
officers in the R. 0. T. C. unit
at the University. The purpose of the club is to promote
and maintain interest in R. 0.
T. C. on the campus. The
club is being sponsored by
Scabbard and Blade, honorary military society. Membership will be limited to cadet
officers who, upon becoming
officers, will automatically attain membership in the Service
Club.

GEOLOGY CLUB TAKES BAY TRIP
RESULTING IN WET FEET AND D. T.'S
Although three men were left on
the wharf madly waving their hats
and uttering various and sundry
noises, the good ship "Geisha" proceeded down the bay on the most
recent geology trip. It seems that
from sixty to seventy men take this
course which requires that trips to
the various existing geological formations about Baltimore be undertaken.
The uninitiate will not appreciate
the dangers undergone by these
fearless men in the pursuit of geologic lore. Many are the miles
traversed in mud and mire in
search of bits of rock and topographical phenomena.

that such a large craft could not
turn in so small quarters.
Soon a crap game was in progress. Although once interrupted
by a request for cash to pay for the
boat, several managed to win
enough to buy an ice cream cone
or two.
Hawkins Point achieved fame by
virtue of having the Davidson
Chemical Company's plant located
there once. The past tense is used
as, not so long ago the factory
was removed through the effects of
dynamite carelessly handled.
The "Geisha" pulled up at the
remains of a pier. It is stated that
several men (Hopkins students)
were so afraid that they had to
he led across the timbers composing
the wharf. Dr. Swartz and Dr.
Watson are also reported to have
laughed heartily at the resultant
sight.
Rallying along the beach for
miles beneath overhanging clifts
with feet bathed alternately by
ocean and mud, various geological
phenomena were observed by the
wandering geologists and due note
taken.
Vieing in popularity with the R.
0. T. C. command, "Company Dismissed," or the words "Lecture
Concluded." At the issue of the
latter the future geologists broke
into a run and soon arrived at the
palatial yacht to inveigle one or two
members who had a little wealth
still remaining in a game of chance.

FIRST COTILLION AT
MARYLAND CASUALTY
It was recently announced
by the Cotillion Board that
the first Cotillion would be
held Thursday, December 19,
from 9 until 1, at the Maryland Casualty Hall, with Jack
Lederer furnishing the music.
The price of admission will be
$2.50 per couple and $2.00
stag. Punch and other refreshments will be served.
The regular Saturday night
dance will be held tomorrow,
in Levering Hall. Admission
will be as usual, $1.00 per
couple or stag. Os Steinwald
and his orchestra will play. A
door prize will be presented
to the lucky couple.

EDITORIALS
ON WINTER EVENINGS
OLD weather has its compensations. Wintry evenings were made,
we suspect, for those of us to whom a fireside glow, a comfortable chair and a good book represent the acme of perfect content.
While the wind, in chilling blasts, sweeps through chimneys and bends
tree-tops, a book is an appreciative friend. It is queer what a potent
charm a mere physical object like a soft deep armchair can exert to
lure us into its warm embrace. How swift the hours fly by, once we
are caught up in the pages of our companion book.

C

Dickens lends himself admirably to winter reading. There is a
certain horny feeling in his tales which seems to fit in with the surrounding environment of comfort on the inside and piercing cold
without the door. His characters are either cheerful cosy creations
who fit in with the warmth of a gently stirring fire or else miserable,
dank villains who remind us forcibly of our own comfort. Somehow,
Dickens never seems to go well with us in summer. Tiny Tim and
Scrooge divorced from their proper season are feeble unreal creatures.
But cold wind and snow breathe life itself into this otherwise empty
shell of words which portrays them.
Tales of adventure and romance, ballads and epics of ancient times
exert their greatest effect on such evenings. With the shadows playing around us, and perhaps the sound of music coming softly from
a radio near at hand, olden days and glorious deeds of half-forgotten
valour do not seem at all impossible. The heroes of the printed page
actually step from the surrounding blackness and salute us.
Less intellectual but nevertheless of ever stronger appeal when the
stars sparkle over a whitened countryside are mystery tales. In the
silence of an empty house, nothing is more conducive to real enjoyment than an "honest to goodness- tale of horror. We shall never
forget the thrill of first reading "Dracula" on just such a night. With
only the occasional creaking of a floor board or the howling of the
wind, that fateful ride of Jonathan Harker into the Transylvanian
haunts of Count Dracula actually seemed real. Every lurch and jolt
of those dashing steeds of the night echoed from the empty space
around us. And finally when under warm covers, sleep came on that
awful picture of the vampire count still haunted us.
Unfortunately there are all too many to whom the pleasures of evenings thus spent are as yet unknown. Undoubtedly, some would scorn
such tame pursuits, yet if they could be induced to spend but one
evening under lamplight with only a book for a companion, we venture to predict, they would become converts. Many a story of early
pioneers, tells of hours spent before a flickering fire reading after the
arduous labors of the day were over. Now comforts of modern
civilization have softened the conditions, but the pleasure is all the
more enhanced thereby.
When the mercury drops near the bottom, choose a warm spot in
your favorite corner, take a book with you wisely selected and soon
you will be speeding into realms of fancy out of reach of the winds
outside. Only when the clock strikes long and loud will you come
P. W. S.
back to earthly spheres.

INTERCOLLEGIATE NEWS
Professor Moore of the McGill
Pharmacy College, in a lecture to
the Pharmaceutical Society, told
them that the Fijis manufacture a
liquor which killed a British sailor
three days after he took a drink.
Over here in the United States
they manufacture liquor which will
kill even a college student one minute after being swallowed.
In a contest between the mighty
University of Southern California
football team of last year and a
group of pretty chorines, the
chorus outclassed the team. The
highest kick on the football team
was two feet one inch and on the
chorus squad two feet ten inches.
Some newspapers are sponsoring
co-ed football games now. So do
the football men.
In the University of Vermont
the freshmen measure up to the
sophomores, according to statistics
compiled by their military officials.
Perhaps that is the reason why the
sophomores play touch-football up
there.
The dream of a decade was
realized wizen the bell in the tower
of Packer Hall tolled out the 13to-12 victory over Lafayette. Not
since 1918 has the old bell thrilled
the hearts of the Lehigh rooters
with its message of joy.
At Lehigh the boys will now be
able to get their physical education
credit by playing indoor golf. The
golf course is being installed in the
gym by the college authorities.
The aviators of tomorrow in the
University of Michigan are finding
that the path of the pioneer is not
bestrewn with roses. A notice published at the behest of the office of
the dean extend the automobile ban
to include aeroplanes. University
students may be airminded, but if
they wish to stay in Ann Arbor
they must keep their feet on the
gi ound.
The horse population in Wyoming is 147,988, while the number
of automobiles is only 56,698.
No team won the Middle Three
championship this year because of
the peculiar results of the games
played between the three contenders, Lafayette, Rutgers and Lehigh. Each of the teams lost one
and won one game in the series.
It took a year's work on the part
of Oregon U. students to produce
their own movie "Ed's Co-ed."
"Ed's Co-ed" is the longest, most
elaborate and most expensive film
ever produced by an American minizersity or college group, according
to its co-producers, Camel Nelson
and Jim Saley. It took all fall to
get permission and all of the winter to get supplies. Here's a college picture where the collegian
doesn't get drunk or jazz crazy.
The students of the Brooklyn
Centre College of New York City
have started a hospital fund drive
for the benefit of injured members
of athletic teams. So far $160
has been raised. The immediate
cause of the establishment of the
permanent fund was the injury
sustained by one of the college's
best football players in a recent
game.
The University of Washington
',lammed to stage a monster pajama
parade last Friday night as a feature of the homecoming rally to be
staged before the Stanford game.
But—President M. Lyle Spencer
came forth with the verdict that a
parade of that sort would be rather
indelicate, so old clothes were worn
instead.
It snowed in Westwood, California, last Friday. Four, and
sometimes five or six white crystals
drifted down through the carefully
prepared apparatus that had formed
them. They brought to a climax
six years of research at the University of California and completed a physical phenomenon never
before accomplished artificially—

the formation of snow crystals
from vapor.
The Meds at McGill swear to a
special Latin oath used since 1848,
since the old Hippocratic oath is
now impracticable for it forbids the
practice of surgery.
Students at the University. of
Vermont were afforded a few minutes' diversion Monday afternoon
at about half past three, by a slight
earthquake which set up tremors
for a few minutes. Prof. Jacobs
explained the disturbance as a
geological readjustment around the
Funchan Fault coming up Cape
Ann.
Northwestern's inimitable dean
of men has just issued a comprehensive symposium depicting the
evils of the proverbial fraternity,
"hell week." In his talk he declares that "hell week" must go.
Yale men have been greatly worried by the mysterious disappearance of one of their most treasured relics—a section of the famous fence. This eight-foot section
is valued at $10,000 by Yale men.
It was stolen on the eve of the
Princeton-Yale game. However, at
a Harvard banquet the gate was
returned by the President of the
Harvard Lampoon.

ome decisions can't
be put off till tomorrow!
The basketball player who took very
long to decide between passing the ball
and trying for a basket would soon lose
his chances to do either.
And the man who keeps putting
off his decision in the choice
of a career may lose his chance
to be very effective at anything.
Isn't it true that not a few men

up to their senior year are still very
uncertain what work to take up after
graduation?

kins Y. M. C. A. will hold a conference for Hopkins students on
"An Interpretative Study of Religion." This is the first attempt at
this University to hold a conference solely for Hopkins students.
However, it is thought that this
problem is of greater interest to the
student body than manifested on the
surface.
The open meeting will be held at
2.30 P. M. Saturday, and sessions
will continue until 9.30. On Sunday, the group will meet at 9.30
A. M. and the closing address will
be delivered at 2.30 P. M. All students are invited. There will be no
registration fee.
The speakers will be Rev. T.
Gutherie Speers, of Brown Memori
al Church; Charles E. McAllister,
St. Michaels and All Angles; Frank
C. Bancroft, Princeton '26, and VirMichaels and All Angels; Frank C.
Bancroft, Princeton '26, and Virginia Seminary, '30, and Harry E.
Foalkrod, Y. M. C. A Secretary of
the University of Maryland. An
important feature of the conference will be the discussion groups
held after each address. The publicity on the conference asks the
following questions among others:
"What Sort of God Can an Intelligent Man Believe in, if Ally?" "If
One Call Believe in God, What of
it?","-What About the Bible?", and
"What Is the Need of Religion
Anyway?"

Mr. Williams to Speak
At International Tea

Last year the Hopkins squad had
a rather good season. Off to a
flying start, Hopkins' series of unbroken triumphs was only halted by
defeat at the hands of the very
'strong Temple team. Georgetown,
• one of the most powerful basketball teams in the country last year,
defeated Hopkins only by playing
an extra period. With two big
rivals, Hopkins broke even. These
were the University of Maryland
and St. Johns. Hopkins won one
(Tame and lost one to each.

Last Wednesday afternoon the
first of a series of tea-dances held
for graduate students and faculty
members was held in Levering Hall.
These tea-dances are bein held
under the auspices of a committee
of graduate students. Marshall
Spaulding, student in Political
Science, is the chairman. Mrs.
Berry poured tea at the last gathering. Mrs. David N. Robinson will
pour the tea next Wednesday from
4 to 6 in Levering Hall. All graduate students and faculty members
are invited to attend the dances.
A dance will be held by the same
body the night of December 13th.
The plans for the party will be announced at a later date.

A special meeting of the Liberal
Club will be held today to hear
Howard Y. Williams of the League
for Independent Political Action
discuss current trends in the American political situation.
Mr. Williams is well known in
liberal circles both as a writer and
a lecturer. At present he is engaged in awakening sentiment in
behalf of a vigorous third party
movement. The group that he represents is a new power in American politics and consists largely of
those liberals and independents
who, under the leadership of John
Dewey, so enthusiastically supported Norman Thomas in the recent
New York mayoralty campaign.
The meeting will be held at 1
P. M. today in Room C, Levering
Hall. The Liberal Club cordially

this interesting topic.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, DECEMBER 6, 1929

Vol. XXXIV, No. 19

CADET OFFICERS
PLAN SERVICE CLUBS
Plans for the formation of
the Service Club will be decided on and drawn up at a
meeting to be held on Monday, December 9, at 3:45
P. M., on the second floor of
Levering Hall. This meeting
will be held for all the cadet
officers in the R. 0. T. C. unit
at the University. The purpose of the club is to promote
and maintain interest in R. 0.
T. C. on the campus. The
club is being sponsored by
Scabbard and Blade, honorary military society. Membership will be limited to cadet
officers who, upon becoming
officers, will automatically attain membership in the Service
Club.

RESULTING IN WET FEET AND D. T.'S
Although three men were left on
the wharf madly waving their hats
and uttering various and sundry
noises, the good ship "Geisha" proceeded down the bay on the most
recent geology trip. It seems that
from sixty to seventy men take this
course which requires that trips to
the various existing geological formations about Baltimore be undertaken.
The uninitiate will not appreciate
the dangers undergone by these
fearless men in the pursuit of geologic lore. Many are the miles
traversed in mud and mire in
search of bits of rock and topographical phenomena.

FIRST COTILLION AT
MARYLAND CASUALTY
It was recently announced
by the Cotillion Board that
the first Cotillion would be
held Thursday, December 19,
from 9 until 1, at the Maryland Casualty Hall, with Jack
Lederer furnishing the music.
The price of admission will be
$2.50 per couple and $2.00
stag. Punch and other refreshments will be served.
The regular Saturday night
dance will be held tomorrow,
in Levering Hall. Admission
will be as usual, $1.00 per
couple or stag. Os Steinwald
and his orchestra will play. A
door prize will be presented
to the lucky couple.

EDITORIALS
ON WINTER EVENINGS
OLD weather has its compensations. Wintry evenings were made,
we suspect, for those of us to whom a fireside glow, a comfortable chair and a good book represent the acme of perfect content.
While the wind, in chilling blasts, sweeps through chimneys and bends
tree-tops, a book is an appreciative friend. It is queer what a potent
charm a mere physical object like a soft deep armchair can exert to
lure us into its warm embrace. How swift the hours fly by, once we
are caught up in the pages of our companion book.

C

Dickens lends himself admirably to winter reading. There is a
certain horny feeling in his tales which seems to fit in with the surrounding environment of comfort on the inside and piercing cold
without the door. His characters are either cheerful cosy creations
who fit in with the warmth of a gently stirring fire or else miserable,
dank villains who remind us forcibly of our own comfort. Somehow,
Dickens never seems to go well with us in summer. Tiny Tim and
Scrooge divorced from their proper season are feeble unreal creatures.
But cold wind and snow breathe life itself into this otherwise empty
shell of words which portrays them.
Tales of adventure and romance, ballads and epics of ancient times
exert their greatest effect on such evenings. With the shadows playing around us, and perhaps the sound of music coming softly from
a radio near at hand, olden days and glorious deeds of half-forgotten
valour do not seem at all impossible. The heroes of the printed page
actually step from the surrounding blackness and salute us.
Less intellectual but nevertheless of ever stronger appeal when the
stars sparkle over a whitened countryside are mystery tales. In the
silence of an empty house, nothing is more conducive to real enjoyment than an "honest to goodness- tale of horror. We shall never
forget the thrill of first reading "Dracula" on just such a night. With
only the occasional creaking of a floor board or the howling of the
wind, that fateful ride of Jonathan Harker into the Transylvanian
haunts of Count Dracula actually seemed real. Every lurch and jolt
of those dashing steeds of the night echoed from the empty space
around us. And finally when under warm covers, sleep came on that
awful picture of the vampire count still haunted us.
Unfortunately there are all too many to whom the pleasures of evenings thus spent are as yet unknown. Undoubtedly, some would scorn
such tame pursuits, yet if they could be induced to spend but one
evening under lamplight with only a book for a companion, we venture to predict, they would become converts. Many a story of early
pioneers, tells of hours spent before a flickering fire reading after the
arduous labors of the day were over. Now comforts of modern
civilization have softened the conditions, but the pleasure is all the
more enhanced thereby.
When the mercury drops near the bottom, choose a warm spot in
your favorite corner, take a book with you wisely selected and soon
you will be speeding into realms of fancy out of reach of the winds
outside. Only when the clock strikes long and loud will you come
P. W. S.
back to earthly spheres.

INTERCOLLEGIATE NEWS
Professor Moore of the McGill
Pharmacy College, in a lecture to
the Pharmaceutical Society, told
them that the Fijis manufacture a
liquor which killed a British sailor
three days after he took a drink.
Over here in the United States
they manufacture liquor which will
kill even a college student one minute after being swallowed.
In a contest between the mighty
University of Southern California
football team of last year and a
group of pretty chorines, the
chorus outclassed the team. The
highest kick on the football team
was two feet one inch and on the
chorus squad two feet ten inches.
Some newspapers are sponsoring
co-ed football games now. So do
the football men.
In the University of Vermont
the freshmen measure up to the
sophomores, according to statistics
compiled by their military officials.
Perhaps that is the reason why the
sophomores play touch-football up
there.
The dream of a decade was
realized wizen the bell in the tower
of Packer Hall tolled out the 13to-12 victory over Lafayette. Not
since 1918 has the old bell thrilled
the hearts of the Lehigh rooters
with its message of joy.
At Lehigh the boys will now be
able to get their physical education
credit by playing indoor golf. The
golf course is being installed in the
gym by the college authorities.
The aviators of tomorrow in the
University of Michigan are finding
that the path of the pioneer is not
bestrewn with roses. A notice published at the behest of the office of
the dean extend the automobile ban
to include aeroplanes. University
students may be airminded, but if
they wish to stay in Ann Arbor
they must keep their feet on the
gi ound.
The horse population in Wyoming is 147,988, while the number
of automobiles is only 56,698.
No team won the Middle Three
championship this year because of
the peculiar results of the games
played between the three contenders, Lafayette, Rutgers and Lehigh. Each of the teams lost one
and won one game in the series.
It took a year's work on the part
of Oregon U. students to produce
their own movie "Ed's Co-ed."
"Ed's Co-ed" is the longest, most
elaborate and most expensive film
ever produced by an American minizersity or college group, according
to its co-producers, Camel Nelson
and Jim Saley. It took all fall to
get permission and all of the winter to get supplies. Here's a college picture where the collegian
doesn't get drunk or jazz crazy.
The students of the Brooklyn
Centre College of New York City
have started a hospital fund drive
for the benefit of injured members
of athletic teams. So far $160
has been raised. The immediate
cause of the establishment of the
permanent fund was the injury
sustained by one of the college's
best football players in a recent
game.
The University of Washington
',lammed to stage a monster pajama
parade last Friday night as a feature of the homecoming rally to be
staged before the Stanford game.
But—President M. Lyle Spencer
came forth with the verdict that a
parade of that sort would be rather
indelicate, so old clothes were worn
instead.
It snowed in Westwood, California, last Friday. Four, and
sometimes five or six white crystals
drifted down through the carefully
prepared apparatus that had formed
them. They brought to a climax
six years of research at the University of California and completed a physical phenomenon never
before accomplished artificially—

the formation of snow crystals
from vapor.
The Meds at McGill swear to a
special Latin oath used since 1848,
since the old Hippocratic oath is
now impracticable for it forbids the
practice of surgery.
Students at the University. of
Vermont were afforded a few minutes' diversion Monday afternoon
at about half past three, by a slight
earthquake which set up tremors
for a few minutes. Prof. Jacobs
explained the disturbance as a
geological readjustment around the
Funchan Fault coming up Cape
Ann.
Northwestern's inimitable dean
of men has just issued a comprehensive symposium depicting the
evils of the proverbial fraternity,
"hell week." In his talk he declares that "hell week" must go.
Yale men have been greatly worried by the mysterious disappearance of one of their most treasured relics—a section of the famous fence. This eight-foot section
is valued at $10,000 by Yale men.
It was stolen on the eve of the
Princeton-Yale game. However, at
a Harvard banquet the gate was
returned by the President of the
Harvard Lampoon.

kins Y. M. C. A. will hold a conference for Hopkins students on
"An Interpretative Study of Religion." This is the first attempt at
this University to hold a conference solely for Hopkins students.
However, it is thought that this
problem is of greater interest to the
student body than manifested on the
surface.
The open meeting will be held at
2.30 P. M. Saturday, and sessions
will continue until 9.30. On Sunday, the group will meet at 9.30
A. M. and the closing address will
be delivered at 2.30 P. M. All students are invited. There will be no
registration fee.
The speakers will be Rev. T.
Gutherie Speers, of Brown Memori
al Church; Charles E. McAllister,
St. Michaels and All Angles; Frank
C. Bancroft, Princeton '26, and VirMichaels and All Angels; Frank C.
Bancroft, Princeton '26, and Virginia Seminary, '30, and Harry E.
Foalkrod, Y. M. C. A Secretary of
the University of Maryland. An
important feature of the conference will be the discussion groups
held after each address. The publicity on the conference asks the
following questions among others:
"What Sort of God Can an Intelligent Man Believe in, if Ally?" "If
One Call Believe in God, What of
it?","-What About the Bible?", and
"What Is the Need of Religion
Anyway?"

Mr. Williams to Speak
At International Tea

Last year the Hopkins squad had
a rather good season. Off to a
flying start, Hopkins' series of unbroken triumphs was only halted by
defeat at the hands of the very
'strong Temple team. Georgetown,
• one of the most powerful basketball teams in the country last year,
defeated Hopkins only by playing
an extra period. With two big
rivals, Hopkins broke even. These
were the University of Maryland
and St. Johns. Hopkins won one
(Tame and lost one to each.

Last Wednesday afternoon the
first of a series of tea-dances held
for graduate students and faculty
members was held in Levering Hall.
These tea-dances are bein held
under the auspices of a committee
of graduate students. Marshall
Spaulding, student in Political
Science, is the chairman. Mrs.
Berry poured tea at the last gathering. Mrs. David N. Robinson will
pour the tea next Wednesday from
4 to 6 in Levering Hall. All graduate students and faculty members
are invited to attend the dances.
A dance will be held by the same
body the night of December 13th.
The plans for the party will be announced at a later date.

A special meeting of the Liberal
Club will be held today to hear
Howard Y. Williams of the League
for Independent Political Action
discuss current trends in the American political situation.
Mr. Williams is well known in
liberal circles both as a writer and
a lecturer. At present he is engaged in awakening sentiment in
behalf of a vigorous third party
movement. The group that he represents is a new power in American politics and consists largely of
those liberals and independents
who, under the leadership of John
Dewey, so enthusiastically supported Norman Thomas in the recent
New York mayoralty campaign.
The meeting will be held at 1
P. M. today in Room C, Levering
Hall. The Liberal Club cordially
invites every one interested to at-

Mr. Howard Y. Williams, of
New York City, Executive Secretary for the League for Independent
Political Action, will speak at the tend.
International Tea Sunday, on
"Europe Ten Years After the
War." The meeting will be held as
usual in the parlor of Levering
Hall at 5 o'clock. All students from
foreign nations studying in Baltimore and their friends are invited
to attend this informal gathering
and to discuss with Mr. Williams
this interesting topic.
